Description: Broad-spectrum antibiotic for dermal; urinary and respiratory infections. Available in multiple tablet sizes (22.7mg; 68mg; 136mg) with flexible dosing
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; photosensitivity; seizures (rare)

Description: Combination antibiotic effective against Staphylococci and other bacteria. Most common dosage 6.875mg per pound every 12 hours. Available in multiple formulations
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; allergic reactions; nausea

Description: Broader spectrum penicillin derivative. More resistant to stomach acids than penicillin. Typical dosage 5-12mg/lb twice daily. Use for 5-7 days or 48 hours after symptoms resolve
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; allergic reactions; diarrhea

Description: First-generation cephalosporin for superficial/deep pyoderma and soft tissue infections. Effective against Gram-positive bacteria
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; allergic reactions; potential cross-reactivity with penicillin

Description: Essential for upper/lower respiratory infections and obligate intracellular bacteria treatment. May cause photosensitivity and esophageal ulceration if not properly swallowed
Common_Side_Effects: Photosensitivity; gastrointestinal upset; esophageal ulceration

Description: Recommended first-line for canine/feline pyoderma in many countries. Also for anaerobic infections. Injectable forms available for life-threatening infections
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; pseudomembranous colitis; esophageal ulceration

Description: Effective against wide range of bacteria. Used for respiratory infections; UTIs; and certain skin conditions. Available in tablet form
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; photosensitivity; esophageal irritation

Disease_Treatment: Anaerobic bacterial infections; protozoal infections; Giardia
Description: For anaerobic bacteria and protozoal enteric infections. Also used for Giardia treatment. Bitter taste requires careful administration in cats
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; metallic taste; neurological effects (at high doses)

Description: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory approved for canine use. First-line arthritis medication. Available as tablets or beef-flavored chewables
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; gastric ulceration; reduced appetite; lethargy

Description: NSAID for osteoarthritis and orthopedic surgery pain. Oral liquid formulation allows precise dosing for small breeds. Long-acting; convenient once-daily dosing
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; reduced appetite; diarrhea; kidney function concerns

Description: Specifically designed for post-surgical pain (bone/joint surgery). Can be used short-term or long-term for arthritis. Available in multiple tablet strengths
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; gastric ulceration; reduced appetite

Description: Newer NSAID approved in 2004. For osteoarthritis and orthopedic/soft-tissue surgery. Can be used short-term or long-term. Requires careful monitoring
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; reduced appetite; diarrhea

Description: Novel pain-blocking mechanism targeting NGF receptor. Designed for dogs needing GI-friendly option. EP4 antagonist interrupts pain signaling pathway
Common_Side_Effects: Diarrhea; vomiting; decreased appetite (less likely than traditional NSAIDs)

Duration_Frequency: Every 3-4 days for 4 weeks; then every 4 weeks
Description: Disease-modifying osteoarthritis drug. Slows arthritis progression and promotes cartilage repair. Requires multiple vet injections. Effects take weeks to develop. Benefits working/performance dogs
Common_Side_Effects: Injection site reactions; mild swelling

Disease_Treatment: Chronic pain; neuropathic pain; nerve pain
Description: For moderate to severe nerve pain and chronic pain. Alternative to gabapentin. Long-term therapy with strict monitoring. Requires gradual titration
Common_Side_Effects: Sedation; ataxia; lethargy; weight gain

Disease_Treatment: Chronic pain; neuropathic pain; anxiety; pre-visit sedation
Description: For chronic/neuropathic pain and anxiety. Cats particularly responsive to pre-visit anxiety reduction (10+ hours sedative effect). Multiple daily dosing; requires titration
Common_Side_Effects: Sedation; ataxia; lethargy (cat dosing more pronounced)

Disease_Treatment: Moderate to severe pain; arthritis pain
Description: Multimodal analgesic for pain management in NSAIDs-intolerant animals. Requires gradual titration. Multiple daily dosing protocol
Common_Side_Effects: Sedation; nausea; constipation; seizures (rare)

Disease_Treatment: Ringworm; yeast infections; systemic fungal infections
Description: Cost-effective antifungal for skin/systemic fungal infections. Cats more prone to liver toxicity (use alternatives if possible). Available in 200mg tablets. Monitor liver function
Common_Side_Effects: Hepatotoxicity; gastrointestinal upset; decreased appetite; skin reactions

Disease_Treatment: Dermatophyte infections; yeast dermatitis; systemic fungal infections
Description: Preferred over ketoconazole for most fungal infections. Increased efficacy and fewer adverse effects. Available as coated bead capsules and suspension (10mg/ml)
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; hepatotoxicity; decreased appetite

Disease_Treatment: Systemic fungal infections; Cryptococcus (CNS); yeast dermatitis
Description: Excellent CNS penetration for fungal meningitis/brain infections. Good for resistant fungal infections. Similar spectrum to itraconazole with key differences
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; hepatotoxicity; headache

Description: First-generation antihistamine with sedative effects. Less effective for chronic allergies than newer antihistamines (cetirizine more effective in studies)
Common_Side_Effects: Drowsiness; dry mouth; urinary retention; paradoxical hyperactivity (rare)

Description: Second-generation antihistamine with minimal drowsiness and 24-hour duration. More effective than diphenhydramine for chronic allergies. Proven efficacy in dogs
Common_Side_Effects: Minimal drowsiness; mild digestive upset; excessive salivation (rare)

Description: 24-hour second-generation antihistamine with minimal sedation. Suitable for daytime allergy protection. Cats typically 5mg (half tablet) once daily
Common_Side_Effects: Minimal drowsiness; mild GI upset

Description: First-generation antihistamine effective when others fail; particularly for respiratory symptoms. OTC but fewer formulations available
Common_Side_Effects: Drowsiness; dry mouth; urinary retention

Disease_Treatment: Severe allergic reactions; severe pruritis; anxiety
Description: Reserved for severe allergic reactions when other antihistamines fail. Also used for anxiety. More sedating than other antihistamines
Common_Side_Effects: Sedation; dry mouth; urinary retention

Disease_Treatment: Vomiting; nausea; post-operative nausea; motion sickness
Description: Neurokinin-1 receptor antagonist. Injectable forms for severe cases. Effective for vomiting but less effective for nausea-associated behaviors. Common in veterinary hospitals
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; injection site reactions (if IM); decreased appetite

Disease_Treatment: Severe nausea and vomiting; chemotherapy-induced nausea
Description: 5-HT3 receptor antagonist for severe nausea/vomiting. More effective than maropitant for nausea-associated behaviors. Off-label use in veterinary medicine
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; headache; constipation (rare)

Duration_Frequency: Every 8-12 hours (high dose) or Every 12 hours (low dose)
Description: Dopamine antagonist promoting gastric motility. Less expensive but less effective than ondansetron/maropitant. Requires higher doses in dogs (1mg/kg) for antiemetic effect
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; restlessness; diarrhea

Disease_Treatment: GERD; gastroduodenal ulceration; gastric acid reduction
Description: Reduces gastric acid; indicates for gastric ulcers; oesophagitis; NSAID-related ulcers. Often overprescribed. Now available OTC; markedly reduced cost
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; headache; vitamin B12 deficiency (long-term use)

Disease_Treatment: Gastroesophageal reflux; gastric ulcers; gastric acid reduction
Description: H2 receptor antagonist reducing gastric acid. Less potent than PPIs but fewer interactions. Useful for mild GERD or gastric upset
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; diarrhea; minimal side effects

Description: Protective coating for ulcerated GI tract. Forms barrier protecting damaged tissue. Requires administration separate from other medications (2 hours before/after). Suspension often used for cats
Common_Side_Effects: Constipation; gastrointestinal upset (rare)

Description: Synthetic T4 replacement for hypothyroidism. Lifelong daily therapy required. Initial dose 0.02mg/kg twice daily; adjusted based on blood tests every 2-4 weeks. Must give on empty stomach
Common_Side_Effects: Increased appetite; excessive thirst; increased urination; weight loss; hyperactivity

Description: T3 thyroid hormone for levothyroxine-refractory hypothyroidism. Short half-life requires three-times daily dosing. May cause hyperthyroid-like symptoms; less predictable than levothyroxine
Common_Side_Effects: Hyperactivity; increased appetite; excessive thirst; anxiety

Description: Intermediate-acting human recombinant insulin. Initial dose differs based on glucose levels. Dogs typically require more frequent injections than cats
Common_Side_Effects: Hypoglycemia; injection site reactions; lipodystrophy

Description: Long-acting basal insulin popular in cats. Twice-daily administration improves glycemic control and improves diabetic remission rates in cats. Requires blood glucose monitoring
Common_Side_Effects: Hypoglycemia; injection site reactions; lipodystrophy

Description: Long-acting basal insulin used in diabetes management. Duration 18-24 hours. Used as alternative to glargine in resistant cases
Common_Side_Effects: Hypoglycemia; injection site reactions; lipodystrophy

Description: Oral diabetes medication for Type II diabetic cats with functioning beta cells. Stimulates pancreatic insulin release. Requires low-carbohydrate diet and monitoring. May lose efficacy after weeks/months
Common_Side_Effects: Hypoglycemia; gastrointestinal upset; hepatotoxicity

Disease_Treatment: Atopic dermatitis; autoimmune diseases; transplant rejection
Description: Calcineurin inhibitor for atopic dermatitis and autoimmune conditions. Requires 4-6 weeks to achieve full effect. Regular monitoring of immunosuppression needed
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; gingival hyperplasia; increased susceptibility to infection

Duration_Frequency: Twice daily (7-14 days); then once daily
Description: Novel JAK inhibitor for allergy-related itching. Rapid onset (24 hours) without systemic immunosuppression. Indicated for canine atopic dermatitis
Common_Side_Effects: Vomiting; diarrhea; pyoderma; urinary tract infections

Disease_Treatment: Inflammation; allergic reactions; autoimmune disease; IBD
Description: Potent anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressant. Reduces inflammation; swelling; allergic reactions. Extended use risks: GI ulceration; immunosuppression; hyperglycemia; osteoporosis
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; increased appetite; increased thirst; urination; obesity; behavioral changes

Disease_Treatment: Anaphylaxis; severe inflammation; central nervous system conditions
Description: Long-acting corticosteroid for severe allergic/inflammatory conditions. IV administration for emergency anaphylaxis. More potent than prednisone; longer duration
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; immunosuppression; behavioral changes; diabetes risk

Disease_Treatment: Feline Leukemia (FeLV); Feline Immunodeficiency Virus (FIV); viral skin conditions
Duration_Frequency: Three times weekly for 2 weeks; then twice weekly
Description: Recombinant interferon boosting immune response against persistent viral infections. Used for FeLV and FIV. Enhances antiviral immune mechanisms
Common_Side_Effects: Injection site reactions; fever; malaise

Disease_Treatment: FIV; FeLV; viral skin conditions; persistent infections
Description: Human recombinant interferon for viral conditions not responding to other therapies. Used for persistent viral infections. Adjunct therapy with other antivirals
Common_Side_Effects: Injection site reactions; fever; flu-like symptoms

Description: Neuraminidase inhibitor for influenza. Efficacy stronger in dogs; used as adjunct for severe parvovirus. May reduce viral shedding and symptom duration
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; vomiting; diarrhea

Disease_Treatment: Feline Herpesvirus-1 (FHV-1); herpes keratitis; upper respiratory herpesvirus
Description: First-line antiviral for feline herpesvirus. Inhibits viral DNA synthesis. Clinical improvement in respiratory and ocular symptoms. Typical dosing 40-90mg/kg orally 2-3 times daily
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; vomiting; diarrhea

Disease_Treatment: Herpesvirus infections; Pacheco's disease (birds); corneal herpes
Description: Generally not first-line for cats (poor bioavailability); used in dogs for herpesvirus. Injections for birds (Pacheco's). Requires frequent dosing. Cats risk reversible leucopenia
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; neurological effects (high dose); reversible anemia (cats)

Disease_Treatment: Severe viral infections; as alternative antiviral
Description: Broad-spectrum antiviral for severe viral infections when other options fail. Teratogenic; monitor liver/kidney function. Limited veterinary use; primarily research/experimental
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; hepatotoxicity; teratogenicity

Disease_Treatment: Skin infections; otitis; yeast dermatitis; bacterial skin infections
Description: Combination topical treatment for mixed fungal/bacterial skin and ear infections. Ointment base; apply to affected areas. Contraindicated in animals with perforated eardrums
Common_Side_Effects: Local irritation; allergic contact dermatitis; systemic absorption if applied to large areas

Disease_Treatment: Otitis media; otitis externa; mixed infections
Description: Complex otologic preparation for mixed bacterial/fungal ear infections. Polyvalent antibiotic + antifungal + steroid combination. DO NOT use if eardrum perforated
Common_Side_Effects: Otic irritation; contact dermatitis; systemic steroid effects (if absorbed)

Disease_Treatment: Bacterial eye infections; corneal infections; bacterial otitis
Description: Broad-spectrum fluoroquinolone for eye/ear bacterial infections. Delivered directly to infection site. Minimal systemic absorption. Avoid in perforation risk scenarios
Common_Side_Effects: Local irritation; photosensitivity (rare); allergic reactions

Disease_Treatment: Conjunctivitis; otitis; keratitis; inflammatory eye/ear conditions
Description: Combined fluoroquinolone antibiotic + anti-inflammatory steroid for bacterial inflammatory eye/ear conditions. Suspension for external use; strong local anti-inflammatory effect
Common_Side_Effects: Local irritation; steroid-related side effects (glaucoma risk with prolonged use >7 days)

Disease_Treatment: Otitis externa; otitis media; mixed infections
Description: Triple-action otologic preparation for mixed bacterial/fungal ear infections with inflammation. Polyvalent antibiotic + steroid + antifungal. Broad spectrum coverage; no ototoxicity at normal doses
Common_Side_Effects: Otic irritation; allergic reactions; contact dermatitis

Disease_Treatment: Otitis externa; mange mites; fungal/bacterial ear infections
Duration_Frequency: 4 drops every 8-12 hours for 7 days (ears); topical as directed (skin)
Description: For mange; fungal; and bacterial ear infections. Thiabendazole active against mange mites; neomycin for bacteria; dexamethasone for inflammation
Common_Side_Effects: Otic irritation; contact dermatitis; allergic reactions; possible systemic effects if absorbed

Disease_Treatment: Canine osteoarthritis pain; chronic pain management
Description: Revolutionary monthly injectable monoclonal antibody targeting NGF (Nerve Growth Factor). Interrupts pain signaling at source. Novel mechanism; safe for cardiac/GI issues. First-only monthly osteoarthritis pain therapy
Common_Side_Effects: Decreased appetite; vomiting; hyperactivity (rare); lameness (rare)

Disease_Treatment: Osteoarthritis support; joint health; cartilage repair
Description: Proprietary formulation with FCHG49 glucosamine + TRH122 chondroitin. Clinically-researched ingredients. Popular for osteoarthritis prevention and management. Requires 4-6 weeks to see effects
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; diarrhea; minimal side effects generally

Disease_Treatment: Osteoarthritis support; joint health; cartilage support
Description: Advanced formulation with ASU (avocado/soybean unsaponifiables) enhancing glucosamine/chondroitin efficacy. Proprietary ingredients with clinical backing. Slow-acting; requires weeks of treatment
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; diarrhea; minimal side effects

Generic_Name: Glucosamine + Green-Lipped Mussel + Fish Oil + Chondroitin
Disease_Treatment: Osteoarthritis support; joint mobility; cartilage health; inflammation reduction
Description: Multi-component supplement with high glucosamine (750mg for large dogs); green-lipped mussel (naturally-sourced chondroitin + Omega-3s); fish oil for anti-inflammatory support. Size-specific dosing
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; mild diarrhea; fish oil taste/breath

Disease_Treatment: Joint inflammation; cardiovascular health; skin health; inflammatory conditions
Description: Most evidence-backed ingredient for pet joint health per AAHA. Anti-inflammatory through multiple pathways. Used for osteoarthritis; allergies; skin conditions. Well-established safety
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; fishy breath; diarrhea (at excessive doses)

Disease_Treatment: Osteoarthritis support; joint mobility; collagen synthesis
Description: Innovative formulation with Kynosil technology combining glucosamine with bioavailable silicium for enhanced collagen synthesis. Includes fish collagen (2%). Novel approach to joint support
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; minimal side effects reported

Description: Synthetic pyrethroid for external parasites. TOXIC TO CATS - use only on dogs. Highly effective; long-lasting. Check label for safety on young animals
Common_Side_Effects: Skin irritation; neurological toxicity if ingested; lethargy

Description: Traditional anti-parasitic/antifungal dip. Slower-acting but low toxicity. Used for mange management; fungal infections. Requires repeated applications. Unpleasant smell; yellow discoloration possible
Common_Side_Effects: Skin irritation; yellow staining; odor; nausea if ingested

Disease_Treatment: Mange; lice; some internal parasites; microfilariae
Description: Avermectin antiparasitic for mange mites; lice; microfilariae. DANGEROUS in MDR1-carrying dogs (Collies; Australian Shepherds; others). Regular dosing may cause toxicity. Subcutaneous injection available
Common_Side_Effects: Neurological toxicity (MDR1 dogs); lethargy; nausea; mydriasis

Disease_Treatment: Fleas; mites; parasites; some intestinal worms
Description: Monthly topical avermectin for external parasites. Waterproof after 2 hours. Absorbed systemically; redistribution through skin oils. Safe for dogs and cats (8 weeks+). Non-greasy; rapid action
Common_Side_Effects: Skin irritation; hair loss at application site; neurological effects (rare)

Description: Antiparasitic for internal parasites and heartworm prevention. Active against roundworms; hookworms; whipworms; tapeworms (with praziquantel combination). Monthly dosing. Available in combination products
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; neurological toxicity in sensitive breeds (rare); lethargy

Description: Fast-acting isoxazoline; kills fleas within 3 hours; ticks within 4 hours. Monthly chewable. Good palatability (liver-flavored). Careful monitoring in breed-specific seizure predisposition
Common_Side_Effects: Hyperactivity; tremors; seizures (rare; breed-predisposed); nausea

Description: Isoxazoline for monthly flea/tick prevention. Dogs: beef-flavored; Cats: topical formulation. Effective within 30 minutes. Long-acting; monthly protection. Continued monitoring for neurological safety
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; tremors; seizures (rare); hyperactivity

Description: Newest isoxazoline for monthly flea/tick prevention. Beef-flavored tablet; rapid onset. Safe; well-tolerated in most dogs. Monthly administration. Monitor for breed-specific neurological predisposition
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; tremors (rare); lethargy

Description: Novel long-acting 12-week flea/tick tablet for dogs. Cats receive monthly topical formulation. Rapid onset; highly effective. Convenient quarterly dosing for dogs reduces administration frequency
Common_Side_Effects: Vomiting; diarrhea; lethargy; anorexia

Description: Avermectin ectoparasiticide. Available as topical or oral formulations. Effective for mange mites and lice. Use with caution in MDR1-carrying breeds. Often used off-label in combination therapies
Common_Side_Effects: Neurological toxicity (MDR1 dogs); skin irritation; neurotoxicity

Description: Macrocyclic lactone for internal parasites and heartworm prevention. Often combined with other antiparasitics (ectoparasitics). Good tissue penetration; prolonged activity. Careful dosing in sensitive breeds
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; neurological toxicity (MDR1 dogs); lethargy

Description: Specific tapeworm medication. Highly effective for cestodes (tapeworms). Single-dose treatment in most cases. May see segmented worms in stool post-treatment; this is expected
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; diarrhea; salivation; headache

Description: Anthelmintic for roundworms and hookworms. Safe for young animals (puppies/kittens); suspension easily dosed. Requires repeat treatment. Often first-line dewormer for intestinal parasites
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; diarrhea; vomiting (rare)

Disease_Treatment: Roundworms; hookworms; whipworms; Giardia; lung parasites
Duration_Frequency: Three consecutive days; repeat in 3 weeks if needed
Description: Broad-spectrum anthelmintic. Safe; even in young/pregnant animals. Requires 3-day course for efficacy against most parasites. Particularly effective for Giardia when given for 3 days; repeat in 3 weeks. Available as suspension
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; diarrhea; minimal side effects

Administration_Route: Single application; repeat in 2 weeks if needed
Duration_Frequency: Combination anthelmintic for cats. Topical spot-on application eliminates pilling challenges. Broad-spectrum coverage (intestinal/lung parasites). No-mess administration; effective single dose
Description: Novartis
Manufacturer: Minimal; skin irritation at application site possible

Description: Combination anthelmintic with microfilarial activity. Multiple parasites covered in single dose/product. Often used as heartworm prevention + deworming combination
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; neurological toxicity in sensitive breeds (ivermectin component)

Description: Advanced fluoroquinolone with improved tissue penetration; particularly effective for respiratory infections
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; photosensitivity; seizures (rare)

Description: Third-generation cephalosporin for serious systemic infections; injectables only; hospital-grade antibiotic
Common_Side_Effects: Injection site reactions; potential cross-reactivity with penicillin

Description: Macrolide antibiotic; particularly effective for anaerobic and atypical bacteria; used for colitis management
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; diarrhea; allergic reactions

Disease_Treatment: Urinary tract infections; prostatitis; protozoal infections
Description: Broad-spectrum sulfonamide combination; particularly useful for UTIs and some protozoal infections
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; allergic reactions; crystalluria (rare)

Disease_Treatment: Chronic osteoarthritis pain; long-term pain management
Description: Extended-release formulation of grapiprant; targets EP4 receptor for chronic pain relief; GI-friendly mechanism
Common_Side_Effects: Diarrhea; vomiting; decreased appetite

Disease_Treatment: Anxiety; fear; storm phobia; post-operative agitation
Description: Antidepressant/anxiolytic with rapid onset; used for acute anxiety and behavioral issues; minimal sedation compared to other options
Common_Side_Effects: Drowsiness; sedation; priapism (rare); tremors

Disease_Treatment: Severe anxiety; panic disorder; seizure threshold reduction
Description: Benzodiazepine anxiolytic for severe anxiety; rapid onset; requires careful monitoring for dependence
Common_Side_Effects: Sedation; ataxia; dependence with long-term use; paradoxical hyperactivity (rare)

Disease_Treatment: Chronic atopic dermatitis; long-term allergy management
Description: Extended-release JAK inhibitor for chronic allergy itch; improved convenience over twice-daily dosing
Common_Side_Effects: Vomiting; diarrhea; secondary infections

Description: Innovative monoclonal antibody targeting IL-31; controls itch source; injectable; convenient 2-4 week dosing
Common_Side_Effects: Injection site reactions; minimal systemic effects

Disease_Treatment: Inflammatory bowel disease; anaerobic bacterial infections
Description: First-line treatment for IBD in dogs and cats; also effective against anaerobic bacteria and protozoa
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; metallic taste; neurological effects at high doses

Description: Prokinetic agent improving gastric motility; used for gastroparesis and nausea-related disorders
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; restlessness; diarrhea

Description: Active S-enantiomer of omeprazole; enhanced potency; used for severe acid-related conditions
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; vitamin B12 deficiency (long-term); headache

Description: Long-acting PPI for severe GERD and ulceration; excellent CNS penetration for unusual presentations
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; vitamin B12 deficiency (long-term)

Disease_Treatment: Dilated cardiomyopathy; congestive heart failure; mitral insufficiency
Description: Positive inotrope and vasodilator; improves cardiac contractility and reduces preload; given twice daily with food
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; tachycardia; arrhythmias

Disease_Treatment: Congestive heart failure; hypertension; protein-losing nephropathy
Description: ACE inhibitor reducing cardiac workload; slows disease progression in CHF; commonly used long-term
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; hyperkalemia; acute kidney injury (in certain conditions)

Description: Adrenolytic agent inhibiting cortisol synthesis; used to treat hyperadrenocorticism; requires ACTH stimulation monitoring
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; electrolyte imbalances; acute adrenal insufficiency

Description: Adrenolytic chemotherapy agent for adrenocortical tumors; less commonly used than trilostane; requires intensive monitoring
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; neurological effects; electrolyte imbalances; hepatotoxicity

Disease_Treatment: Bacterial skin infections; respiratory infections; UTIs
Description: Fluoroquinolone with enhanced tissue penetration; particularly effective for resistant skin infections
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; photosensitivity; seizures (rare)

Disease_Treatment: Serious bacterial infections; systemic infections; septicemia
Description: Injectable fluoroquinolone for hospital-grade infections; rapid systemic delivery; used for serious systemic infections
Common_Side_Effects: Injection site reactions; retinal toxicity in cats at high doses; seizures (rare)

Description: Broad-spectrum dewormer; granule formulation for easy administration; effective against resistant parasites
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; diarrhea; vomiting

Description: Fast-acting topical flea killer; kills adult fleas within 2 hours; waterproof after 24 hours
Common_Side_Effects: Local skin irritation; allergic reactions; hair loss at application site

Disease_Treatment: Flea control; flea allergy dermatitis prevention
Description: Insect growth regulator preventing flea egg/larvae development; effective flea population control
Common_Side_Effects: Minimal; rare gastrointestinal upset

Disease_Treatment: Acute flea infestation; rapid flea kill
Duration_Frequency: Single dose (repeat in 30 days if needed)
Description: Rapid-acting oral flea treatment; kills adult fleas within 30 minutes; good for acute infestation
Common_Side_Effects: Gastrointestinal upset; excitability; tremors (rare)

Description: Injectable marbofloxacin for serious infections; improved tissue penetration versus oral
Common_Side_Effects: Injection site reactions; photosensitivity; seizures (rare)

Disease_Treatment: Anxiety-related behaviors; obsessive-compulsive disorder; separation anxiety
Description: SSRI antidepressant for behavioral disorders; slower acting than other anxiolytics; requires 2-4 weeks for full effect
Common_Side_Effects: Sedation; gastrointestinal upset; urinary retention; cardiac arrhythmias

Description: Injectable antiemetic for severe vomiting; faster onset than oral; preferred in hospitalized animals
Common_Side_Effects: Injection site reactions; decreased appetite; gastrointestinal upset
